Isabel Guijarro a, Sagrario Mendioroz a,., Vicenta Mufioz b a Inst. Catdlisis y Petroleoqu(mica, CSIC, Campus U.A.M. Cantoblanco, 28049 Madrid, Spain b Dept. de Qu(mica lnorgdnica y Qu(mica Tfcnica, U.N.E.D., Senda del Rey S/N, 28040 Madrid, Spain Received 29 March 1995; revised 1 July 1995; accepted 1 July 1995 Abstract Three samples of naturally occurring sepiolite from different deposits in Spain were used as catalysts for the Claus reaction 2nH2S + nSO2 ~ 3n/xS~ + 2nH20 (AH= - 109.2 kJ mol-I ) at low tempera- tures ( < 400 K), to purify sulphur compounds (H2S and SO2) from tail-gas. The process was carded out in a fluidized bed reactor of the semicontinuous type on a semi-pilot scale. The sulphur produced in the reaction condenses on the solid surface contributing to its deactivation by fouling. Sulphur incorporation into the solid is governed by internal diffusion of the reactants in microdomains of the porous network, the factors affecting the latter being of capital importance in the occupation degree of the solid. The textural characteristics of the catalysts supports were studied by porosimetric techniques: nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and mercury intrusion. Two pore-plugging mechanisms, the wedge layered (WLM) and the complete layered (MMM) mechanisms are described and applied to the porosimetric data of the sulphurized samples in order to ascertain the number of layers penetrating the system, Significant differences in the pore filling were observed by the appli- cation of the models which were related to factors affecting reactant diffusivity within the porous network: texture of the involved solids, working temperature (373-473 K) and reactant concentration (2-4% v/v H2S). Significant conclusions regarding the possibilities of sulphur recovery, in relation to the texture of the solids involved, may be reached in this study, but also, and more general, regarding parameters affecting catalyst deactivation by fouling. Keywords: Fouling; Super-Claus; Sepiolite; Desulphurization; Flue gases 1. Introduction In a previous paper [ 1 ], we have studied the Claus reaction at low temperature (358-400 K) as a method for the preparation of sulphurized substrates to be used * Corresponding author. 0926-860X/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDI 0926-860X ( 95 )O01 63-8 336 M.L Guijarro et aL /Applied Catalysis A: General 132 (1995) 335-351 as mercury scavengers [2]. At the working temperature, H2S conversions were close to 100% [ 3,4] and the sulphur produced, below its dew point, was deposited on the catalytic bed, with a build-up on the substrate of ordered layers whose extension and further performance were strongly dependent on the reaction para- meters and the texture of the solid. The rate of deposition was found to decay with sulphur content in the substrate but in no case ceased completely. Sepiolite was used as catalyst substrate [ 5 ] and the kinetics of sulphur deposition under different sets of conditions were studied. Having effected an estimation of the amount of sulphur coating the solid, it was found that, (i) quantities as low as 1 g sulphur per 100 g sepiolite are sufficient to cause the loss of microporosity of the substrate, probably due to plugging of the pore mouths, (ii) the activity is maintained at an acceptable levels much longer than that of one sulphur monolayer covering the solid surface, values up to 100 g/ 100 g sepiolite having been detected prior to deactivation. This suggests that, (iii) sulphur itself is a catalyst for the reaction, once the active sites of the substrate are covered by the deposit [6]. The results observed [ 1 ] seem to indicate that the surface reaction is very fast, the transport phenomenon being the rate determining step of the process. However, at the working conditions, mass transfer limitations cannot exist because the process was carried out in a fluid bed reactor with use of particle size of ca. 250/~m. Then, the limitations could be imposed by internal diffusion in microdomains of the porous network of the solid, as it is progressively occupied by sulphur deposited after reaction. Since conversion is very high, the porous system of the solid becomes rapidly occupied by sulphur. Thus, limitations to the flow of reactants within the porous network would arise practically from the commencement of the reaction. Sulphur molecules (SA) are 13.8.05 ,~ in size [7] and their effect in the dimensions of pores of less than 50 nm in diameter, i.e. mesopores, cannot be disregarded. If this is the case, the actual pore radius which is a function of the number of deposited sulphur layers, would finally determine a lower diffusion coefficient with a lower mass transfer and lower effectivity of the catalytic bed. Butt [ 8] indicated that ultimate penetration of a coke type foulant into a catalyst particle is very quickly reached and subsequent deposition occurs entirely within an outer shell. The phenomenon is of general occurrence. Consequently, the porous network of the substrate, which the fouled material inherits in a more or less modified form, must have the appropriate texture to receive the contaminant without significant alteration of its original properties in order to preserve the life and efficiency of the solid. In our case, sulphur plays the role of foulant and, since both, sulphur and the substrate, are equally active towards the Claus reaction, the deac- tivation of the sample must be strictly related to changes in the porous network, not to real poisoning, as a consequence of the sulphur deposit. Thus, the study of the effect of the different operating conditions in the sulphur deposition can be proposed as a model for any other type of foulant. M.L Guijarro et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 132 (1995) 335-351 337 In order to observe the effect of diffusional resistance on the solid activity, three series of tests were designed in which the structure of the catalyst (sepiolite), the reactant concentration and the working temperature, were successively changed and their effect in the sulphur deposition mechanism studied in samples with a similar sulphur content per gram of fresh sepiolite. This paper discusses the results obtained. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials Three minerals, with the composition and structural characteristics of sepiolite, a magnesium silicate, with formula SilaMg8Oao(OH)4(H20)4.8H20, from differ- ent Spanish deposits were used. One of these, SB, from Vallecas (Madrid) supplied by Tolsa S.A., is a very pure sepiolite with an impurity content (mainly quartz and dolomite) below 10%. The others, SM1 and SM2 are from different sites in the deposit of Teruel and were supplied by Myta S.A. They are of lower purity, with sepiolite contents below 60%. The physico-chemical properties of these materials are given in Table 1. 2.2. Reaction The experimental system is shown in Fig. 1 and consists mainly of (a) preheater and mixer, (b) reactor and (c) auxiliary equipment and absorber for purification of the exhaust gas. The preheater is a 20 cm long stainless steel conic cylinder of 10 cm diameter connected to the reactor at the upper end, filled with raschig rings to increase the area for heat exchange. The reactor, of the fluidized bed type, is a 40 cm high cylinder of 10 cm diameter, made of stainless steel (AISI 304L) with the lower part joined to the preheater, separated by a stainless steel sieve of 0.05 mm aperture width which permits a uniform distribution of gas in the bed. The static bed height was about 17 cm in all cases. The upper part of the reactor is joined to a glass cylinder of the same diameter and 90 cm height for cooling the gases and recovery of the solid. The reactor was electrically heated by a wired Kanthal resistance wound on the outside of the walls and regulated by a P.I.D. controller. The temperature was maintained with a stability of _ 1 K. To sustain the fluid bed, an air flow of 27 L min- 1, provided by a compressor, Incoinsa, of 25 1 capacity and 14 bars pressure, was used. H2S and SO2 are supplied by SEO with a purity of N27 and N30, respectively. The flow was regulated by needle valves and measured by rotameters. A chamber located before the heater allows the mixture of the air with the reactants. The reactor worked in a semi-continuous regime, discontinuous for the solid and continuous for the gas. The solid in each run ( 1 kg) was first dried in an oven at 380 K for 24 h, then loaded in the reactor. The exhaust gases are purified from the fine particles in a cyclone and retained in a 4 M sodium hydroxide scrubber, in series with the reactor. 3. General outlook In order to study the effect of various parameters on the sulphur deposition, a simulation was devised in which the geometry of the pores was considered as cylindrical with variable radius r and the same length L, with a total overlapping between voids and throats distributions and pore range between 1.5 and 7000 nm. Successive steps of complete monolayers of Sa, octo-chains 22 ,~2 cross-sectional area and 13.8 A length as the most probable sulphur allotrope under the work conditions [ 7 ] were assumed. The calculations are applied to the pore-size distri- butions of the parent materials as obtained from the application of the BJH method [9] to nitrogen adsorption--desorption data and the Washburn equation [ 10] to mercury intrusion data for meso- and macroporosity, respectively. As departure point 1.5 nm is taken because sulphur molecules cannot penetrate pores below this size [4] ; thus, the simulation was applied to the fresh sample after having subtracted from the data the surface area and pore volume corresponding to micropores, which was not considered in the description of the porous structure model. (More details are given in [ 1 ], and references therein). Two deposition mechanisms as idealized extremes of the real situation were considered: a mono-multilayer mechanism (MMM) by which an ordered deposi- tion of complete sulphur layers along the internal wall of the pores is built up [ 11 ], and a wedge layered mechanism (WLM) [ 12] by which the foulant accumulates by simultaneous penetration into the pores and thickening on their walls in a quantity depending on the thickening/penetration ratio (Fig. 2). There are consequently two effects on the sulphur deposition process: one related to the specific activity of the solid and dependent on the nature of the substrate, concentration of reactants and temperature, and the other to deactivation, which could be related to (a) a slow modification of the activity by irreversible chemisorption-poisoning of reactants (SO2 ~ SO4~ ) [ 12] and/or products (sulphur and water) on the active sites, and (b) changes in texture and hence in surface area and porosity by fouling of the remaining solid. Under the chosen set of conditions, the latter prevails; with high enough temperatures, above the dewpoint, sulphur should not deposit, but only condense in the capillary pores of the solid in an extension given by the Kelvin equation, and a steady state in the Claus reaction could, eventually, be reached [4]. In order to see how the texture of the solid affects diffusivity after sulphurization, exhaustive textural analysis was effected on the samples, through nitrogen adsorp- tion-desorption at 77 K and mercury intrusion porosimetry. In Fig. 4 the porosimetric data are shown for samples SB, SM2 and SM1, curves a, b and c, fresh (solid lines) and sulphurized (dotted lines) respectively, as obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and mercury intrusion. From the curves, textural parameters were calculated and gathered in Table 4. According to the data shown, surface area and microporosity decay dramatically with the sulphur deposition, meso- and macroporosity being less affected. As can be seen, the losses in pore volume do not balance the measured sulphur content, assuming a density of 2 g/cm3 for the deposited sulphur, neither the ratio between the calculated and the experimental values is the same in all three samples. This may be an indication that sulphur has produced different blockage of the pores as corresponding to a different pore size distribution in the samples. Under reaction conditions, gaseous reactants invade the porous structure of the solid and sulphur layers are built on the walls as they are reached by the reactants: a monolayer should first cover the solid surface, unless restrictions are present in any part of the porous system, in whose case, not all the sites will be accessible to M.I. The threshold for both mechanisms is not strictly dependent on the pore size and an influence of the remaining pore distribution (and activity) seems to appear. Thus, a complete penetration (MMM) does not occur up to 30 nm in sepiolites SM 1 and SM2, whereas the threshold is 18 nm in SB. In contrast, penetration below those pore sizes, is smaller in sample SB followed by SM1 and SM2. In Fig. 7a the pore size distribution of the fresh samples is shown: a large incidence of macroporosity, along with a smaller one of mesoporosity in samples SM 1 and SM2 with respect to SB can be seen. According to that distribution and the number of layers deposited, (Fig. 6), the sulphur volume occupying every range of pore size, was calculated by application of expressions (3) and (4) and depicted in Fig. 7b. As may be observed, sulphur deposits into the whole pore network but its distribution, apart of some irregularities, is slightly skewed towards the larger sizes in every range of pores. In a previous paper [ 13 ], we described the porous network as interconnected constrictions (throats) and openings (voids) whose statistical properties can be described by two distributions: one for the throats, and one for the voids. The porous structure depends on the packing effi- ciency of the constituent particles and is a function of their symmetry properties. Depending on the kind of porous structures, the possibility of overlapping of both elements -- throats and voids-- is different. If any disturbing element (in shape 346 M.I. Guijarro et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 132 (1995) 335-351 and size) is present in the samples (particles of different nature for example), this ideal disposition will be affected and constrictions should occur. Sepiolite, as has been described elsewhere [ 14] is a hydrosilicate, of structural formula Si~2Mg803o(OH)4(H20)4-8H20, with a fibrous morphology with micro- crystalline channels 10.8 4.0 .~ size parallel to the fibres. Its two axes symmetry gives rise, through aggregation, to bundles of needles with parallel sided non- intersecting pores of variable radius not larger than the particle diameter, micro- mesopores. Many packing orientations are possible among bundles, resulting, together with the previous system of parallel pores, in interconnected throats and voids of similar size, macroporous in size. On sepiolite SB, with a high density of meso-micropores, the gases find some difficulty to diffuse, increased by the fast reaction on the developed surface area of the pore walls; as a consequence, the penetration degree in smaller mesopores ( < 4 nm), is small (x= 2/L) but the quantity of sulphur deposited therein is high, specially around 22 nm coinciding with the maximum in porosity. In contrast, sepiolites SMI and SM2, with an important component of macroporosity, give an easy way to reactants which penetrate more deeply (x = 1L) the smaller pores, but result in a smaller amount of sulphur deposited. For a given amount of deposited sulphur, the smaller the quantity deposited in the mesopores shell of the samples, the higher the number of layers formed in the macropores (samples SM1 and SM2), thus resulting in an occupancy which is slightly skewed towards the larger sizes. Besides, the latter samples present a relatively high content of carbonates and iron oxides (more in SM1 ) with a different activity and morphology (granular against acicular) that can alter the connectivity of the pores affecting the reactants' diffusivity. This last point can explain the differences detected in sulphur location between SM1 and SM2, in spite of their similar pore distribution. With respect to deactivation, the value of the constants shown in Table 4 is a consequence of both effects, 'initial activity' and internal diffusivity inside the pore system of the samples as controlling the reaction. On sorbents of different origin, but not very different in activity, Cew must be strictly related to the porous system of the solids: mean pore radius, pore size distribution an connectivity, in combination with the fluid dynam- ics of the system. Four different cases can be quoted: when the activity is high and the structure open, reaction is effected on the surface as well as in the inner porous system, the degree of occupancy is high and the deactivation low (SM2). If, by contrast, the texture is closed, the reaction mainly occurs on the surface, but also on the pore walls, resulting in sample deactivation through pore clogging by the sulphur produced (SB). When activity is low and the pore system open, reactants penetrate easily, a homogeneous distribution of the foulant is produced, the degree of occupancy is high and the deactivation low. Finally, if the pore system is closed, the degree of penetration may be high and also the deactivation (SM 1 ). Comparing the actual sulphur content of the samples (12%) with that calculated from the application of the models assuming a sulphur density of 2 g/cm3, the fitness degree is much better on SM2 (9.9%) than on SB (8.2%), indicating the importance of M.I. Under the studied conditions, a pore range between 20 and 200 nm (Fig. 6) seems critical and a relation between its volume (Table 4) and aw (Table 3) is apparent. The effect of reactant concentrations was studied on SM1 at 400 K in two series with equimolecular mixtures of H2S and SO2 and concentrations of 2 and 4% in volume. From the corresponding porosimetric data and following a simulation like in the previous case, the curves corresponding to samples with 7% sulphur content were simulated and shown in Fig. 8 altogether with the measured data. It appears that the higher the reactant concentrations, the larger the penetration into the pores. In fact, working with 2% v/v, the reactants can hardly penetrate the meso- and small-macropores of the solid, and the deposits fit a WL model with different values for the parameters x and h (Fig. 9): at first, a scarce penetration occurs which gradually increases up to 3/4L in pores around 35 nm size. Above this size, an increase of the thickening/penetration (h/x) ratio is apparent, but pore sizes larger than 150 nm are necessary for the reactants to enter freely into the porous system and a deposition in complete monolayers following the MM model to occur. In contrast, complete monolayers are built above 16 nm working with 4% v/v of reactants, penetration never being, under such circumstances, smaller than 1/6L. Conclusions The oxidation of H2S by SO2 at low temperature, below 400 K, using sepiolite as a catalyst, has proved to be a useful tool for increasing the sulphur recovery after the high temperature Claus process. At this temperature, below the dewpoint, all the produced sulphur condenses and is deposited on the solid surface resulting in catalyst deactivation by fouling. As the reaction proceeds, mass transfer limitations in microdomains of the sample appear and transport phenomena become the process determining step. All the reaction parameters affecting diffusivity, pore radius distribution, reactant concen- tration, temperature, have an influence on the shape of the deposits and, finally, on the activity and deactivation of the catalyst used. Under the reaction conditions, Micropores are useless in the solid, because they are normally lost with the first gram of sulphur produced, $8 being the dominant 350 M.I. Guijarro et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 132 (1995) 335-351 allotrope at the working temperature. Mesopores and small macropores, by con- trast, are critical because the reactants can diffuse less and less towards the solid active surface as sulphur deposits are produced in voids and throats of the porous network, leaving the solid inactive. There are no diffusional limitations to the reactants in the macroporous system of the solid up to the studied level. Therefore, an open structure seems more favourable when the solid is to be used as adsorbent or potentially fouled catalyst ( such as is the case in the Claus reaction at low temperature). As a consequence, sepiolite, especially SM2, has received an important amount of sulphur (up to 100 g per 100 g of solid) without important losses in activity under the stated working conditions. With the energetics involved, higher concentrations of reactants also drive to a better distribution of the fouling agent in the porous network of the solid and, as a consequence, to a better proficiency without deactivation. (Concentrations of 2 as well as 4% v/v of SH2 can be surely depurated) The effect is of general occurrence when fouling, as a consequence of the chem- ical reaction involved, is expected; thus, it would be desirable that the catalyst, in order to prevent deactivation, has a high pore volume, mainly in macropores, (rp < 200 nm) together with a very correlated structure with no constrictions, in which throats and voids have almost the same radii, and a degree of overlap as near as possible to unity. This kind of open structure should allow a better reactant flow through the voids, which would ultimately result in greater activity and longer life of the catalyst. Three samples of naturally occurring sepiolite from different deposits in Spain were used as catalysts for the Claus reaction 2nH2S+ nSO2→3n/xS x + 2nH2O (ΔH = −109.2kJ mol−1) at low temperatures (< 400 K), to purify sulphur compounds (H2S and SO2) from tail-gas. The process was carried out in a fluidized bed reactor of the semicontinuous type on a semi-pilot scale. The sulphur produced in the reaction condenses on the solid surface contributing to its deactivation by fouling. Sulphur incorporation into the solid is governed by internal diffusion of the reactants in microdomains of the porous network, the factors affecting the latter being of capital importance in the occupation degree of the solid. The textural characteristics of the catalysts supports were studied by porosimetric techniques: nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and mercury intrusion. Two pore-plugging mechanisms, the wedge layered (WLM) and the complete layered (MMM) mechanisms are described and applied to the porosimetric data of the sulphurized samples in order to ascertain the number of layers penetrating the system. Significant differences in the pore filling were observed by the application of the models which were related to factors affecting reactant diffusivity within the porous network: texture of the involved solids, working temperature (373–473 K) and reactant concentration (2–4% v/v H2S). Significant conclusions regarding the possibilities of sulphur recovery, in relation to the texture of the solids involved, may be reached in this study, but also, and more general, regarding parameters affecting catalyst deactivation by fouling.
